content.question:

Your portfolio is now worth $4,250.
What do you do?

objectives.description: Compare investment platforms: robo-advisors, online brokerages, and investment apps for different needs.
Identify how behavioral biases affect investment decisions and your personal susceptibility.
Weigh costs, benefits, and appropriate use cases for robo-advisors vs. DIY investing.
Create rules-based systems that counter emotional decision-making during market volatility.

terms.definition: Automated service using algorithms to build and manage your portfolio based on goals and risk tolerance.
terms.example: Betterment, Wealthfront, Vanguard Digital Advisor. Fee: 0.25%-0.50%/year.

terms.definition: Platform where YOU buy and sell investments yourself with full control over decisions.
terms.example: Fidelity, Charles Schwab, E*TRADE. $0 commissions for stocks/ETFs.

terms.definition: Losses feel about 2x more painful than equivalent gains feel good.
terms.example: You hold losers too long hoping to recover, sell winners too quickly to lock in gains.

terms.definition: Overweighting recent events and assuming current trends will continue forever.
terms.example: Buy high after markets rise, panic sell low after declines. Classic wealth destroyer!

content.headerTitle: Platform Costs: What You Actually Pay

leftPanel.title: $10,000 Invested for 30 Years @ 7%
paragraphs:
Robo-Advisor (0.40% total fees):
Ending Value: ~$70,000
Fees Paid: ~$14,000 over 30 years

DIY Index Funds (0.08% fees):
Ending Value: ~$74,000
Fees Paid: ~$3,000 over 30 years
Difference: $4,000 over 30 years. Is automation + behavioral protection worth it? That's personal.

content.headerTitle: Why Behavioral Biases Cost You Real Money

leftPanel.title: The Investor Behavior Gap
paragraphs: Research consistently shows investors underperform the investments they own:
S&P 500 Returns: 10.7% annually (1992-2021)
Average Equity Investor: 7.1% annually
Gap: 3.6 percentage points lost to behavioral mistakes.
This gap comes almost entirely from buying high (after markets rise) and selling low (after markets fall)‚Äîexactly what biases cause.

highlightBox.text: � Understanding YOUR biases can recover those lost percentage points. Psychology matters more than platform choice!

content.headerTitle: Build Systems to Counter Your Biases

layoutData.title: Rules-Based Investing Beats Emotional Investing
paragraphs: Create rules BEFORE volatility hits. When emotions run high, you follow the rules‚Äînot your gut.
bulletPoints: Rule 1: "I will invest $X every month regardless of market conditions"
Rule 2: "I will not check my portfolio more than once per quarter"
Rule 3: "I will not sell during crashes unless my goals fundamentally change"
Rule 4: "I will rebalance once per year, not in response to market moves"
Rule 5: "Before buying any stock, I must write down 3 reasons I might be wrong"
Rule 6: "I will automate as much as possible to remove emotion from the process"

keyPoint.text: üéØ The right platform can ENFORCE good behavior‚Äîautomatic investing, rebalancing, and barriers to panic selling.

scenario.name: Keisha: Robo-Advisor Success
paragraphs: At 24, Keisha started her first job with $5,000 saved and $200/month to invest. She was overwhelmed by options and honest with herself‚Äîshe'd likely chase performance on Robinhood.
She chose Betterment. Set up automatic $200 monthly deposits. The platform built a 90/10 stock/bond portfolio and handled rebalancing automatically.
During the 2022 drop, friends panic-sold. Keisha's automation kept her investing. Behavioral protection worth more than the 0.25% fee.

scenario.name: Marcus: Pandemic Panic Survived
paragraphs: Marcus, 28, had $18,000 invested when COVID-19 hit in March 2020. Markets crashed 34% in 23 days. His portfolio fell to $11,880.
Every bias screamed SELL: Loss aversion (pain was acute), Recency bias (felt like decline would continue), Herd mentality (friends were selling).

But Marcus remembered his rule: "Never sell based on short-term movements." He kept investing $300/month through the crash, buying at 30% discounts. By August: $24,000. Friends who sold? Locked in losses.

scenario.name: Jasmine: Confirmation Bias Trap
paragraphs: Jasmine, 26, loved sustainable energy and invested $3,000 in a solar company at $45/share. She followed solar news obsessively, joined Reddit communities, and only read positive articles.
Warning signs she missed: declining margins, lost contracts, competitor advances. Stock fell to $38‚Äîshe saw it as a "buying opportunity."

A friend asked: "What would make you sell?" Jasmine couldn't answer. She forced herself to read critical analyses, discovered real problems, sold half at $38. The stock eventually fell to $25. Her diversification into a clean energy ETF saved her.

takeaways.title: Match Platform to Personality
takeaways.description: Robo-advisors for hands-off, brokerages for DIY enthusiasts, apps for beginners‚Äîno single best choice.

takeaways.title: Everyone Has Biases
takeaways.description: Loss aversion, recency, confirmation, herd mentality affect even experts. Intelligence doesn't protect you.

takeaways.title: Psychology > Platform Choice
takeaways.description: The 3.6% behavior gap costs more than any platform fee. Mastering your biases is the biggest win.

takeaways.title: Build Rules-Based Systems
takeaways.description: Create investing rules BEFORE volatility hits. Automate to remove emotion. Follow rules, not feelings.
